Carbonate electrolytes are one of the most desirable electrolytes for high-energy lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) because of their successful implementation in commercial Li-ion batteries. The low-polysulfide-solubility feature of some carbonate solvents also makes them very promising for overcoming the shuttle effects of LSBs. However, regular sulfur electrodes experience undesired electrochemical mechanisms in carbonate electrolytes due to side reactions. In this study, we report a catalytic redox mechanism of sulfur in propylene carbonate (PC) electrolyte based on a comparison study. The catalytic mechanism is characterized by the interactions between polysulfides and dual N/O functional groups on the host carbon, which largely prevents side reactions between polysulfides and the carbonate electrolyte. Such a mechanism coupled with the low-polysulfide-solubility feature leads to stable cycling of LSBs in PC electrolyte. Favorable dual N/O functional groups are identified via a density functional theory study. This work provides an alternative route for enabling LSBs in carbonate electrolytes. Graphical Abstract A catalytic redox mechanism for lithium-sulfur batteries is reported to prevent side reactions of polysulfides in carbonate electrolyte. Keywords Energy storage Lithium-sulfur battery Catalytic redox reaction Porous carbon Carbonate electrolyte 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) are a promising energy storage system because they can have an energy density 3–5 times higher than that of state-of-the-art energy storage devices, i.e., lithium-ion batteries [1–4]. However, despite intense efforts, great challenges remain for their development [5–8]. LSBs commonly employ ether-based electrolytes, e.g. 1,3-dioxolane (DOL)/1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) electrolytes [9–14]. The electrochemical redox cycle of sulfur cathodes in ether-based electrolytes involves the production of the electrolyte-soluble intermediates of lithium polysulfides [15–17]. The dissolution of polysulfides into the electrolytes plays an important role in giving a high capacity of sulfur because solvated polysulfides facilitate the transport of Li+ in the electrode [18–20]. However, polysulfide dissolution is also associated with shuttle effects [1,16,21]. This leads to poor cyclability, low Coulombic efficiency, and self-discharge of LSBs. An alternative approach to overcome the issues caused by ether-based electrolytes is using an electrolyte with low solubility of polysulfides [22–24]. In this regard, carbonate-based electrolytes turn out to be very promising for LSBs as some carbonates have been reported to be a poor solvent for polysulfides [25–28]. The poor-solvent feature makes carbonate-based electrolytes very attractive for LSBs. However, sulfur usually experiences undesired electrochemical mechanisms in carbonated electrolytes, resulting in low electrochemical activity and low capacity, with extreme examples of being completely non-chargeable [29–31]. The low capacity is usually attributed to the compatibility issues between polysulfides and carbonate electrolytes because the side reactions between them consume the active sulfur [29,31]. However, via advanced material/electrolyte designs, sulfur has been demonstrated to be able to deliver a high capacity in carbonate-based electrolytes [26,32–34]. There are three typical routes that provide feasible electrochemical mechanisms for the reduction of sulfur to Li2S in carbonate electrolytes. The first route uses very small-pore carbons as host materials to confine sulfur. The pores are small enough to allow the presence of only small sulfur molecules, i.e., S n , (n ≤ 4), in the pores [33,35]. These pores are micropores with a size less than the molecular size of S5, ~0.5 nm. The electrochemical reduction process during cycling is considered to involve the formation of only low-chain polysulfides (Li2S n , 2 ≤ n ≤ 4) and Li2S [35]. Such a process is different from that in ether-based electrolytes as the intermediates (Li2S n , 2 ≤ n ≤ 8) are different. The second route involves the incorporation of sulfur into an organic framework to obtain organosulfur-based polymer, such as sulfurized polyacrylonitrile [26,32,36,37]. Sulfur atoms are covalently linked to the backbone of the polymer. Although the final discharge product (Li2S) is the same as sulfur, there is the formation of R-S n -Li (R stands for organic groups) in carbonate electrolyte for organosulfur-based polymer in the electrochemical reduction process [26,36]. The third route entails the creation of a protective film on the surface of electrodes. This can be achieved by using a highly concentrated carbonate electrolyte, e.g., 4–6 mol L‒1, which leads to the in-situ formation of an SEI layer on the sulfur electrodes [24,27,38–40]. In addition, the protective film can also be pre-formed by coating techniques, such as alucone-coated sulfur/mesoporous carbons by molecular layer deposition [30,41]. Through these strategies, side reactions can be largely avoided in carbonate electrolytes. However, such strategies have their own drawbacks. For example, the sulfur contents in the materials are low, generally ~40% or even much lower, when using the micropore-confinement and organosulfur strategies. The film protection strategy uses expensive high-concentration electrolytes or costly processing procedures. Thus, it remains a great challenge to enable LSBs in carbonate-based electrolytes. Advancing the performance of LSBs in carbonate-based electrolytes requires developing advanced sulfur/electrolyte systems with a favorable electrochemical mechanism. In this work, we present a catalytic route for the electrochemical redox of sulfur in propylene carbonate (PC) electrolyte. The catalytic redox is characterized by the interactions between polysulfides and dual N/O functional groups on the host carbon. Such interactions stabilize polysulfides in the carbonate electrolyte, and thus, largely prevent side reactions between polysulfides and the carbonate electrolyte. Such a redox mechanism coupled with the low-polysulfide-solubility feature enables stable cycling of LSBs in PC electrolyte. The content of sulfur embedded in the host carbon in our work is up to 52 wt%. This work gives an alternative route to use carbonate electrolytes in LSBs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis 3 g of glucosamine hydrochloride was dissolved in 15 mL of deionized water and sealed into an autoclave followed by hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitates were washed with deionized water via centrifugation and dried at 80 °C under vacuum overnight. The dried powders were mixed with KOH in a precursor/KOH ratio of 1:2 (by weight). The mixture was heated at 750 °C for 2 h. Afterward, the sample was washed with ~5 mol L‒1 HCl and deionized water, and then dried at 80 °C under vacuum overnight. The obtained porous carbon is denoted as N/O-C. 4.5 g of glucose was dissolved in 15 mL of deionized water and sealed into an autoclave followed by hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitates were washed with deionized water via centrifugation and dried at 80 °C under vacuum overnight. The dried powders were mixed with KOH in a precursor/KOH ratio of 1:4 (by weight). The mixture was heated at 750 °C for 2 h. Afterward, the sample was washed with ~5 mol L‒1 HCl and deionized water, and then dried at 80 °C under vacuum overnight. The obtained porous carbon is denoted as O-C. A melt-diffusion method was used to prepare sulfur/carbon composites [42,43]. The prepared porous carbons (N/O-C and O-C) and a commercial porous carbon Ketjenblack EC-600JD were used as the host materials of sulfur. Sulfur was first mixed with a porous carbon at desired ratios and then heated at 160 °C for 16 h to obtain a sulfur/carbon composite. The sulfur content in the composite was calculated based on the weight of the sample before and after heat treatment. 2.2 Characterizations Elemental composition was determined using a Vario El elemental analyzer. N2 adsorption analysis was performed using a QUADRASORB SI/MP (Quantachrome Instruments) at ‒196 °C. Before measurement, the samples were degassed at 150 °C for 20 h. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and nonlinear density functional theory (NLDFT) methods were used for the surface area and pore size distribution (PSD) determination using N2 adsorption data. The data evaluation was done using the QuadraWin 5.05. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TA Instruments Q500 under N2 atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was carried out with a Shimadzu powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were collected on a JEOL JSM-6340F microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were carried out in a custom-designed ultrahigh vacuum system with a base pressure better than 2 × 10–10 mbar. Al Kα (hν =1486.7 eV) was used as the excitation source for XPS. The measurements were performed at room temperature, and the binding energies were calibrated and referenced to the Fermi level of a sputter-cleaned Ag(110) substrate. The total instrumental energy resolution for XPS was estimated to be about 850 meV (the full width at half-maximum of the Ag 3d peak). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and elemental mapping was done using a JEOL 2100F transmission electron microscope and a JEOL JEM-F200 (URP) operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopic (XANES) study was carried out at Singapore Synchrotron Light Source, XAFCA beamline. For the XANES measurements, the samples were collected after lithiation and de-lithiation and sealed in Kapton tape to prevent oxidation. To prepare a fresh electrode with LTFSI, a fresh electrode was immersed into the electrolyte overnight and then taken out and sealed in a Kapton tape for the XANES measurement. 2.3 Computational method All the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out by using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP), carrying out the projected augmented wave (PAW) model. The exchange and correlation effects were described by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional, within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) approach. The cutoff energy was set to be 450 eV for all the calculations. The periodic graphite surfaces were modeled using 5 × 5 supercells. Nitrogen- and oxygen-containing graphite structure models were built based on the perfect graphite supercell. For the structure optimization calculations, a 3 × 3 × 3 mesh was adopted, reciprocally proportional to the surface parameters. When optimizing, all the atoms and the adsorbates were allowed to fully relax until reaching the convergence tolerance. The force and energy tolerance were set to be 0.02 eV Å‒1 and 2 × 10‒5 eV, respectively. For the electronic structure calculation, a 5 × 5 × 3 mesh was adopted. The adsorption energies of species at the surface site were calculated as follows: ∆E ad = E(Li2S8*) ‒ E(Li2S8) ‒ E(*), where E is the total energy obtained directly from DFT calculation. E(Li2S8) and E(*) represent the calculated total energies for the isolated Li2S8 atom and the bare surface. When calculating the adsorption energy of Li2S8, the adsorption site and orientation of the Li2S8 molecule were settled based on the largest overlap of the spatial Fermi softness [44]. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrode preparation. For the ones containing the sulfur/carbon composites, the working electrodes were composed of 85 wt% of sulfur/carbon composites, 5 wt% of Ketjenblack EC-600JD, and 10 wt% of polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF). For the one containing pristine sulfur, the working electrode was composed of 70 wt% of sulfur, 20 wt% of Ketjenblack EC-600JD, and 10 wt% of PVDF. For the one without sulfur, the working electrode was composed of 85 wt% of N/O-C, 5 wt% of Ketjenblack EC-600JD, and 10 wt% of PVDF. The electrode loading was ~1.6 mg cm‒2. A carbon-coated aluminum (MTI Corp.) was used as the current collector for the working electrodes. The electrodes were assembled with lithium metal as a counter electrode in a 2032-type coin cell in an Ar-filled glove box. The electrolyte was 1 mol L‒1 LTFSI (Bis(trifluoromethane) sulfonimide lithium salt, Sigma-Aldrich) in PC (Sigma-Aldrich) or diglyme. 200 μL of electrolyte was used for each cell. A glass fiber (EL-CELL, ECC1-01-0012-C) was used as a separator to keep the electrodes apart. Galvanostatic discharge and charge tests were performed on Battery Testing Equipment (Neware Electronic Co., China) at different current densities at room temperature. The voltage window was between 1.0 V vs. Li+/Li and 3.0 V vs. Li+/Li for the cells tested in the PC electrolyte and between 1.5 V vs. Li+/Li and 2.8 V vs. Li+/Li for those tested using the diglyme electrolyte. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stable cycling of sulfur electrode with dual-N/O-containing carbon in carbonate electrolyte The dual-N/O-containing carbon (N/O-C) used in this study contains 2.6 wt% of nitrogen and 15.5 wt% of oxygen, determined by elemental analysis. The particles of the carbon are irregularly shaped with a size generally larger than 10 µm (Fig. 1(a) ). TEM images (Fig. 1(b) and Fig. S1) show the carbon lacks ordered graphene layers, indicating an amorphous structure. N2 (‒196 °C) adsorption analysis (Figs. 1(c) and (d)) confirms its microporosity. The total pore volume was determined to be 0.745 cm3 g‒1. Sulfur was infiltrated into the pore of the carbon by a melt-diffusion method (Fig. 2(a) ) and the content of sulfur in the obtained S/C composite (S52@N/O-C) was 52 wt%. The sulfur content was calculated by analyzing the weight difference of the sample before and after heat treatment. The value is close to that acquired via TGA (53.6%, Fig. S2). The amorphous feature (Fig. 2(b)) of S52@N/O-C confirms the successful infiltration of sulfur into the pores of the carbon [33,42,45,46]. TEM analysis and corresponding elemental mapping also demonstrate the successful infiltration (Figs. S3 (a)‒(e)). Both carbonate (1 mol L‒1 LiTFSI/PC) and ether (1 mol L‒1 LiTFSI/diglyme) electrolytes were used for cell evaluations. Figs. 2(c) and (d) show charge/discharge profiles of S52@N/O-C in the PC electrolyte. It has a large first discharge capacity of 1549 mAh g–1 at a current density of 50 mA g–1. The charge capacity is ~650 mAh g–1. At a current density of 500 mA g–1, it preserves ~50 % (315 mAh g–1) of the capacity. It is rather stable in the initial 400 cycles (Fig. 2(f)). No shuttle effect can be observed. In contrast, when tested in the diglyme electrolyte, it experiences a typical shuttle effect [47,48], with a voltage maintaining between 2.42 and 2.43 V vs. Li+/Li (Fig. 2(e)) for a capacity larger than the theoretical one (1672 mAh g–1) during the second charge. This shows the advantage of using a poor solvent for polysulfides as an electrolyte. The low solubility of polysulfide in PC is confirmed to be less than 0.05 mol L–1 (total sulfur solubility, Fig. S4), in comparison with the high solubility of up to >10 mol L–1 in ether solvents [28,49]. The carbon host plays an important role in the electrochemical activity of sulfur. This is because regular sulfur/carbon electrodes are non-chargeable in carbonate electrolyte, which is due to the side reactions between carbonate and polysulfides. To confirm this, we used a highly mesoporous carbon (Fig. S5), Ketjenblack EC-600JD (KB), in electrodes. Sulfur was infiltrated into KB (Fig. S6) or simply mixed with KB. Both electrodes show a very low reversible capacity, < 55 mAh g–1 (Fig. S7). This demonstrates the importance of carbon hosts. 3.2 Confirmation of the key effects of functional groups on host carbon The pore size of carbon hosts is usually believed to affect the lithiation process of sulfur as discussed in the introduction [33,35]. The dual-N/O-containing carbon used was microporous (Figs. 1(b)–(d)). To understand whether the microporosity is the key to the activity of sulfur, we used another microporous carbon (O-C, containing 7.8 wt% of oxygen but no nitrogen) with a similar PSD to N/O-C (Figs. 1(c) and (d)) for comparison. O-C has a pore volume of 0.854 cm3 g–1 and its particle size is also generally larger than 10 µm (Fig. S8). Detailed elemental composition and porosity data of the two carbons can be found in Table S1. To improve the utilization of sulfur for mechanism study, sulfur loading in the two carbons was reduced to 20 wt%, denoted as S20@N/O-C and S20@O-C for the one with and without nitrogen, respectively. The successful infiltration of sulfur in the pores of the carbons was also demonstrated by the amorphous feature of the composites (Fig. 3(a) ). The uniform distribution of sulfur in the carbon is shown by elemental mapping (Figs. 3(b)–(h)). The first discharge capacity for S20@N/O-C is 2660 mAh g–1 at 100 mA g–1 in the PC electrolyte (Fig. 4(a) ), much larger than the theoretical capacity and the discharge capacity in the following cycles. This indicates a serious electrolyte decomposition in the first discharge. The charge capacity is stabilized at ~800 mAh g–1. It has a capacity of ~600 mAh g–1 at a current density of 500 mA g–1 (Fig. 4(b)), corresponding to ~1.2 h charging. The capacity is quite stable over 400 cycles (Fig. 4(d)). In contrast, the reversible capacity of S20@O-C is rather low in the PC electrolyte, ~200 mAh g–1 at 100 mA g–1 (Fig. 4(c)). As the PSDs of the two carbon hosts used are almost identical (Fig. 1(d)), the different performances are attributed to the different functional groups of the carbons. 3.3 Study on the sulfur redox processes through XANES To understand the redox processes, we performed a XANES study on the samples during cycling in the PC electrolyte. Figs. 5(a) and (b) show the sulfur K-edge spectra of S20@N/O-C electrodes at different lithiation states. Fig. 5(c) shows the corresponding points chosen for the measurements. The spectra of the two fresh electrodes with and without the electrolyte salt LiTFSI are also given in Fig. 5(a). For the one without LiTFSI, two major peaks are found at 2472.6 and 2482.6 eV. The former is attributed to elemental sulfur; the latter is related to sulfate species formed due to the interactions between sulfur and carbon [50]. For the one with LiTFSI, there is an additional pronounced peak at ~2480.4 eV, due to the presence of LiTFSI which contains the sulfur element. All the discharged and charged electrodes contained LiTFSI, and thus have the same peak. At 2.0 V of the first discharge (Fig. 5(c)), there is a significant capacity of 338 mAh g–1. However, it is interestingly found that the spectrum at 2.0 V of the first discharge is identical to the fresh electrode with LiTFSI. This indicates that the capacity is not derived from the reduction of sulfur, and thus, electrolyte decomposition is dominant during the first discharge process to 2.0 V. The following cycles show negligible capacities when discharged to 2.0 V, indicating the decomposition of the electrolyte has poor reversibility. After the first discharge to 1.0 V, the spectra show a less pronounced peak at 2476.6 eV and a shoulder peak at around 2473.6 eV. For better observation of these two peaks, the spectra at 1.0 V are shown in an enlarged scale in Fig. 5(b), along with the fresh electrodes. These two peaks are ascribed to Li2S [29,51]. Namely, sulfur is reduced to Li2S at the end of the discharge. The capacity from 2.0 to 1.0 V during the first discharge is 2262 mAh g–1, still higher than the theoretical capacity from the reduction of sulfur to Li2S, of 1672 mAh g–1. This indicates that part of the capacity between 2.0 and 1.0 V is also derived from the decomposition of the electrolyte. Upon the first charge to 3.0 V, Li2S is oxidized. However, it was still not completely oxidized to elemental sulfur as the spectrum shows the presence of polysulfides, evidenced by a feature pre-edge peak at ~2470.8 eV [30,51]. This incomplete oxidation contributed to the irreversibility during the first cycle. The spectra of the following cycle show that the second discharge leads to the reduction of polysulfides to Li2S again and that the second charge results in the re-oxidation of Li2S to form polysulfides. The sulfur K-edge spectra of the S20@O-C during the first discharge in the PC electrolyte are shown in Fig. 5(d). The corresponding points chosen for the measurements are shown in Fig. 5(e). These spectra show different sulfur redox behaviors from S20@N/O-C. At 2.0 V of the first discharge, a capacity of 401 mAh g–1 is delivered. A new XANES peak at 2474.1 eV for S@O-C is observed at this voltage. This peak is assigned to the formation of S–C bonds due to the side reactions between polysulfides and the carbonate solvent [27,29,30]. This is in contrast to S@N/O-C where no new peak emerges at 2.0 V. Upon further discharging to 1.0 V, there seems to be a partial break of the S-C because the peak at 2474.1 becomes less pronounced. No Li2S n (1<= n <=8) can be detected at this voltage. For the subsequent charge to 3.0 V, sulfur remains inactive as the spectra are identical for the ones at 1.0 and 3.0 V. Thus, the reversible capacity of S20@O-C should be due to the partially reversible reaction of electrolyte decomposition and the capacitive behavior of O-C (Fig. S9). 3.4 The redox mechanisms of sulfur with dual-N/O-containing carbon in carbonate electrolyte The different electrochemical properties and XANES spectra of S20@N/O-C and S20@O-C show the host carbons have direct impacts on the redox of sulfur. The similarity of PSDs of the two carbons excludes that the differences are derived from the effects of pore size. Thus, in our case, the functional groups on the carbons are responsible for the electrochemical activity of sulfur. This suggests that dual N/O functional groups are involved in the electrochemical reactions of sulfur as a catalyst. This is because no reduced species of sulfur can be found when O-C was used as a host, while a fully reduced product (Li2S) is present at the end of discharge when using N/O-C. The catalytic process should be related to the interactions between dual N/O functional groups and polysulfides. The redox of sulfur is associated with the formation of polysulfides which react with the carbonate solvent. This results in the inactivity of sulfur species during cycling. Regular carbon hosts cannot prevent such side reactions. However, N/O-C appears to be able to largely prevent these side reactions, as evidenced by the presence of Li2S at the end of discharge. This will require that the interactions between N/O-C and polysulfides are much stronger than that between regular carbons and polysulfides, so that N/O-C and polysulfides can form a stable combination ((N/O-C)-Li2S n ) which can be beneficial for maintaining the stability of polysulfides in the carbonate electrolyte. To confirm that N/O-C has strong interactions with polysulfides, we performed a DFT study based on the functional groups determined by XPS. Fig. 6(a) shows the high-resolution XPS C 1s spectrum. Five contributions can be distinguished: (1) SP2-graphitic or C–C/C–H x (47.3%) at 284.8 eV, (2) C–O (33.3%) at 286.3 eV, (3) C=O (10.3%) at 287.9 eV, (4) O=C–O (5.8%) at 289.4 eV, and (5) π–π* shakeup satellite (3.4%) at 291.0 eV [52,53]. The high-resolution XPS N 1s spectrum is shown in Fig. 6(b). Four contributions are identified: (1) Pyridinic-N (16.2%) at 399.0 eV, (2) pyrrolic-N (53.3%) at 400.0 eV, (3) graphitic-N (24.9%) at 400.9 eV, and (4) pyridine-N oxides (5.6%) at 402.3 eV [53–58]. Figs. 7(a)–(f) , Figs. S10 and S11 show the optimized adsorption structures of a typical polysulfide, Li2S8, on the major functional groups according to XPS. Figs. 7(g) and Table S2 summarize the corresponding adsorption energies. The adsorption energy of lithium on pure carbon (graphite) is 1.19 eV (Fig. 7(a)). With the presence of oxygenated groups (Fig. 7(b) and Figs. S10(a)–(c) and Figs. S11(a)–(c)), the highest adsorption energy is –1.06 eV (COOH, Fig. 7(b)). For N/O-containing carbon (Figs. 7(c)–(f), Figs. S10(d)–(n), and Figs. S11(d)–(n)), there are four functional groups exhibiting much higher adsorption energies than pure and oxygen-containing carbon, i.e., –1.91, –1.64, –2.78, and –1.96 eV for graphitic nitrogen (GN) + COOH, pyridinic nitrogen (PDN) + COOH, PDN + COH, and pyrrolic nitrogen (PRN) + C=O, respectively (Figs. 7(c)–(f)). This confirms that dual N/O functional groups on carbon have very strong interactions with Li2S8, which are favorable for stabilizing polysulfides in carbonate electrolyte. Based on our study, we propose that the sulfur redox reactions in carbonate electrolyte can undergo a catalytic process in the presence of N/O-containing carbon. The catalytic process is characterized by the interactions between polysulfides and dual N/O functional groups. Such interactions stabilize polysulfides in carbonate electrolytes and prevent them from side reactions. As a result, polysulfides can be reversibly converted to Li2S during cycling. The redox mechanism in the presence on N/O-containing carbon is illustrated in Fig. 8 , comparing the one with a regular sulfur electrode. 4 Conclusions We showed that PC electrolyte with low polysulfide solubility can work in LSBs when using a dual-N/O-containing carbon as a host for sulfur. The low-polysulfide-solubility feature can minimize the shuttle effects, and thus enhance the cyclability. By comparing two carbon hosts (N/O-C and O-C) with similar porosity and PSDs, we demonstrated that dual N/O functional groups on host carbon affect sulfur redox in PC electrolyte. With the presence of dual N/O functional groups, polysulfides generated during redox processes can be stable in PC electrolyte. Polysulfides can also be fully reduced to Li2S at the end of discharge. This is in contrast to using the N-free carbon host (O-C) where polysulfides are not stable in PC electrolytes due to side reactions. These results suggest that there are strong interactions between dual N/O functional groups and polysulfides which stabilize polysulfides in PC electrolyte. Thus, in the presence of dua N/O functional groups of carbon, the sulfur redox undergoes a catalytic process, characterized by the interactions between polysulfides and dual N/O functional groups. DFT study further confirmed the existence of strong interactions. Four N/O functional groups, i.e., graphitic nitrogen + COOH, pyridinic nitrogen + COOH, pyridinic nitrogen + COH, and pyrrolic nitrogen + C=O, exhibit high adsorption energies towards polysulfides. This work provides an alternative route for enabling Li-S batteries in carbonate electrolytes. coredata.dc:description: Carbonate electrolytes are one of the most desirable electrolytes for high-energy lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) because of their successful implementation in commercial Li-ion batteries. The low-polysulfide-solubility feature of some carbonate solvents also makes them very promising for overcoming the shuttle effects of LSBs. However, regular sulfur electrodes experience undesired electrochemical mechanisms in carbonate electrolytes due to side reactions. In this study, we report a catalytic redox mechanism of sulfur in propylene carbonate (PC) electrolyte based on a comparison study. The catalytic mechanism is characterized by the interactions between polysulfides and dual N/O functional groups on the host carbon, which largely prevents side reactions between polysulfides and the carbonate electrolyte. Such a mechanism coupled with the low-polysulfide-solubility feature leads to stable cycling of LSBs in PC electrolyte. Favorable dual N/O functional groups are identified via a density functional theory study. This work provides an alternative route for enabling LSBs in carbonate electrolytes.
